user_request: A Mother's Day poem about how a mother's love is unconditional.

revision_history.draft:
She left the kettle on again, that old
blue one with the cracked handle she kept
even after the others got replaced.
The coffee maker binged its cycle through,
brew warming up in a cup no one would find.

Three AM. The hall light clicked off
with the quiet precision of something
that has been practicing for years —
and I was gone already, miles wide
between us now on a highway north,
my car humming with its old suspense.

She didn't know I'd notice.
For months I carried the blue mug
around my kitchen like a stone in the shoe,
tasting the cold ring of it every morning,
heating water for no one.

Then: I started keeping a kettle on.
Not because I woke up dehydrated.
Because the house felt wrong without it —
some circuit closed, some household prayer
I'd never memorized but answered anyway.

My daughter finds me now in the kitchen,
stacking plates too neatly, and winces at
the towel still hanging from its peg worn smooth.
She says *you're so organized* like it's a thing
a mother does. Like it's easy.

It isn't. I just have the blue mug again,
heating up nothing. And I watch her set
two cups on the counter, third one wobbling off —
she picks it up and sets it down three more times,
more patient with the glass than she was with me.

Somewhere in there is her mother.
Somewhere in there is a door that clicked
at 3 AM for no reason except someone
needed stillness. And I'm repeating it
the way a dog keeps barking at a shadow —
because the answer was never mine to hold,
just the sound, just the click, just the thing left over.

She doesn't understand yet. But she'll find it.
In the towel that's worn into a shape
only a hand knows. In the mug I keep warming up
for no one. In the kettle that keeps running on
after the house is quiet — because somewhere
a click once meant something and the body
thinks it still does, thinks the house needs it,
thinks the dark has teeth if you let yourself forget.

I didn't leave her anything on paper.
I left the click. I left the thing that keeps
going wrong so someone can get better at
arriving late. At making rooms warm.
At not naming things until it's too late —
when a mouth full of coffee still says nothing,
when a kettle hums its small, persistent song
and no one has to be woken up. Only noticed.

And that is what I passed on:
the ordinary weight of being present
in the version of life where you're not asked
to perform it — just keep handing me
the cup, just keep clicking that door,
just keep letting the house sound like something
someone can come home to, even if they're late.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — a mother who changes everything through domestic ritual, and the child only understanding decades later — is genuinely strong. The poem earns its weight in the second half where repetition and inheritance become visible rather than explained.

"Because the answer was never mine to hold,
just the sound, just the click, just the thing left over."

That line works because it's concrete, unadorned, and does real emotional lifting without reaching for sentimentality. The kitchen sequence (mug, kettle running on after quiet) is where the poem finds its actual shape — specific objects doing symbolic work with restraint.

The closing image of the child handing the speaker a cup: that's earned through everything preceding it. It's not decorative; it's structural.

"The dog keeps barking at a shadow" — this simile lands because it's unexpected and true, where so much domestic poetry defaults to cliché.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché resurgence (lines 9–10):**
> miles wide / my car humming with its old suspense
>
"miles wide" is dead language — it belongs to movies, not lived distance. "Old suspense" is the poem reaching for atmosphere by name. Direction: Cut both. Replace with something that physically describes what a child's departure actually feels like in a kitchen or driveway.

**Abstraction bloat (lines 17–20):**
> some circuit closed, some household prayer / I'd never memorized but answered anyway
>
This is the poem explaining its own metaphor to itself. The reader doesn't need "circuit" and "prayer" — those are abstractions doing the work that "clicking a door at 3 AM" could do in two words. Direction: Cut or compress. Let the action carry weight without taxonomizing it.

**Sentimentality (line 25):**
> Just keep letting the house sound like something
>
This line softens what should be precise and physical — "sound like something." What does it sound like? Direction: Name the actual sound, or cut the line entirely. It's doing emotional work with vagueness.

**Redundancy / padding (lines 27–30):**
> In the towel that's worn into a shape
> only a hand knows.
> In the mug I keep warming up
> for no one.
> In the kettle that keeps running on
>
These three lines are essentially saying the same thing. The kettle line is the strongest; the mug line repeats it without advance. Direction: Keep the kettle or the mug — cut one.

**Weak opening image (lines 1–4):**
> She left the kettle on again, that old
> blue one with the cracked handle she kept
> even after the others got replaced.
> The coffee maker binged its cycle through,

revision_history.draft:
She set two plates on the counter, third one
skidding off and rolling to the edge where
she scooped it up with a butter knife,
careful, almost gentle. Stacked them anyway.
My daughter winces at the towel still
hanging from its peg worn smooth.

Then she found me in the kitchen stacking too,
and I watched her set two cups on the counter—
she picked one up three times before putting it down,
more patient with the glass than she was with me.

Somewhere in there is her mother clicking doors.
Three AM. The hall light practicing its off.
I was already north, my car humming
its old note, miles separating us
on a highway where nothing happens
except the state line signs, lit clearly,
each one saying *welcome* to someone leaving.

She left the kettle on again—the blue one,
handle cracked after the others got replaced.
Coffee maker binged its cycle through.
The mug I keep warming up for no one.
I started keeping it on not because dehydrated
but because the house felt wrong without it—
some circuit closed, some thing I answered
without praying. Just the sound.

My daughter finds me now in the kitchen,
stacking too, and winces. She says *you're so organized*
like it's a thing a mother does. Like it's easy.

It isn't. I just have the blue mug again,
heating up nothing. And I watch her set
two cups on the counter, third one wobbling off—
she picks it up and sets it down three more times,
more patient with the glass than she was with me.

Somewhere in there is a door that clicked
for no reason except someone needed stillness.
I'm repeating it—the way a dog keeps barking
at something behind a fence. Because the answer
was never mine to hold, just the sound,
just the click, just the thing left over.

She doesn't understand yet. But she'll find it—
the towel worn into a shape only a hand knows.
The mug I keep warming up for no one.
The kettle running on after the house is quiet—

because somewhere a click once meant something
and the body thinks it still does, thinks the house needs it,
thinks the dark has teeth if you let yourself forget.

I didn't leave her anything on paper. I left the click.
Left the thing that keeps going wrong so someone can get better at
arriving late. At making rooms warm.
At not naming things until it's too late—
when a mouth full of coffee still says nothing,
when a kettle hums its small, persistent song
and no one has to be woken up. Only noticed.

And that is what I passed on: the ordinary weight
of being present in the version of life where you're not asked
to perform it—just keep handing me
the cup, just keep clicking that door,
just keep letting the house sound like something
someone can come home to, even if they're late.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The kitchen sequence from line 9 onward is where the poem finds its actual shape. "Miles separating us / on a highway where nothing happens" — that compression of distance into a single sentence works. The blue mug with cracked handle (line 8) and the kettle running on after quiet (lines 26–27) are concrete, earned images doing symbolic work without over-explanation.

The closing image — "just keep letting the house sound like something / someone can come home to" — lands because it's grounded in domestic routine. The dog barking at a shadow simile is sharp and specific.

The return of key phrases (the click, the mug warming up for no one) earns repetition through shifting context rather than mere echo.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché avoidance failure:**
The brief's own prohibitions are being violated in places — "I love you" is essentially there as implied sentiment ("some household prayer"), and "putting a smile on my face" appears as "winces at the towel." Direction: Flag every instance where the poem reaches for a greeting-card phrase. Replace with something observed, not inferred.

**Redundancy / structural collapse (lines 25–30):**
> just keep clicking that door,
> just keep letting the house sound like something
> someone can come home to, even if they're late.
>
The three lines essentially say the same thing. "Sound like something" is vague and softens what should be precise — "the front door clicks," "the heater hums." Direction: Choose one line that names the actual sound. Cut or compress.

**Line 14–15 (abstraction):**
> And I was already north, my car humming
> its old note, miles separating us
>
"Old note" is decorative — what does the car actually sound like? The highway metaphor is doing too much work in too few lines. Direction: One image per sentence.

**Line 10 (abstraction):**
> The hall light practicing its off.
>
"Practicing its off" is the poem explaining itself. Direction: Cut or replace with a physical detail — what does the switch actually do?

**Line 23–24 (sentimentality):**
> She doesn't understand yet. But she'll find it.
>
This line narrates feeling rather than building image. Direction: Remove entirely, or replace with something that lets the inheritance be visible in action.

**Line 16 (abstraction):**
> Not because I woke up dehydrated.
>
The negation structure weakens — "Not because" is a dodge. Direction: Write what the habit actually feels like instead of denying convenience.

**Line 3–4 (cliché):**
> She left the kettle on again—the blue one,
> handle

skidding off and rolling to the edge where

Somewhere in there is a door that clicked
for no reason except someone needed stillness.
I'm repeating it—the way a dog keeps barking
at something behind a fence. Because the answer
was never mine to hold, just the sound.

His truck idles its one broken note on the shoulder,
its bright red tail light practicing its single pitch
on the long northbound drag where fog sits
between here and nowhere and nothing happens
except the state line signs, lit clearly,
each one saying *welcome* to someone leaving.

She left the kettle on again—the blue one,
handle cracked after the others got replaced.
Coffee maker binged its cycle through.

heating up nothing. And I watch her set
two cups on the counter, third one wobbling off—
she picks it up and sets it down three more times,
more patient with the glass than she was with me.

The hallway floorboards shift under every step.
I'm repeating it—the way a dog keeps barking
at something behind a fence. Because the answer
was never mine to hold, just the sound,
just the click, just the thing left over.

She says *you're so organized* and I let her keep saying it
while my hands do what they always did:
settle plates, pick up cups, warm mugs for no one.
I don't correct her. The kitchen light practices
its off. Somewhere a floorboard twitches under her shoe.

Because somewhere a click once meant something
and the body thinks it still does, thinks the house needs it,
thinks the dark has teeth if you let yourself forget.

I didn't leave her anything on paper. I left the click.
Left the thing that keeps going wrong so someone can get better at
arriving late. At making rooms warm.
At not naming things until it's too late—
when a mouth full of coffee still says nothing,
when a kettle hums its small, persistent song
and no one has to be woken up. Only noticed.

And that is what I passed on: the ordinary weight
of being present in the version of life where you're not asked
to perform it—just keep handing me
the cup, just keep clicking that door,
just keep letting the house sound like something
someone can come home to, even if they're late.

skidding off and rolling to the edge where
she scooped it up with a butter knife,
